sect2.title: Instance Variables
sect2.para: Instance variables define the state of an object. The are declared within a class definition using the var or def keywords followed by the variable's name, a colon (optional), the variable's type (optional) terminated with a semicolon.

It is possible to declare default values for instance variables (which can later be overridden by values provided in object literals.) The initializers are evaluated in the order the instance variables are specified in the class declaration in the context of the newly created object:

sect2.title: Instance Functions
sect2.para: Instance functions define the behavior of an object. An instance function takes the following form:
where body can be any expression.
Instance functions are first-class objects (they can, for example, be assigned to variables, or passed as parameters to other functions.)
Function parameters are immutable; assignment to them will result in an error.

Functions can also be anonymous. Anonymous functions are often used to assign behavior to the action instance variable of a GUI component:
When overriding a function, use the override keyword. Failure to do so will result in a compile-time error. It is also an error to claim to override when your code actually does not.
